case_data.plaintiff_description: Two Tennessee Tech University professors who put up a flier accusing one of their colleagues of racism and were subsequently disciplined by the University
case_data.summary:
Facts

Turning Point USA (TPUSA) is a conservative organization that publishes profiles of progressive college professors, potentially to harass them. Outsiders, including the two professors, characterize TPUSA as a hate group with ties to white supremacy. Tennessee Tech University (TTU) has a chapter of TPUSA. On February 4, 2021, after witnessing the TTU TPUSA faculty advisor, also a professor, celebrate a local school's decision to maintain "the Redskins" as their mascot, the two professors put up a flier on campus accusing the faculty advisor of racism.

After the faculty advisor complained, TTU's Human Resources department, in conjunction with a staff member from the Office of Research and Economic Development and one from the office of Finance and Planning, conducted an investigation. The investigation concluded that the two professors had violated TTU's Code of Conduct, which mandates, among other things, "integrity and objectivity" through conduct that is "in good faith," "in accordance with the highest ethical and professional standards," and that "promotes academic freedom . . . and respect for all faculty." TTU's Policy 007 also requires that faculty not suppress others' ideas, even if those ideas are widely viewed as offensive or wrong. Following the HR investigation, the Provost of TTU punished the professors by making them ineligible for (1) positions as faculty advisors to student organizations, (2) study abroad activities, (3) non-instructional faculty assignments, and (4) salary increases for a year. Additionally, they were required to meet with the Dean at the start of each semester on the topic of not bringing personal grievances into the workplace, and to complete sensitivity training. The sanctions were set to last through Spring of 2023.

Lawsuit

The professors, represented by private counsel, sued TTU in U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee on October 5, 2021. They alleged under 42 U.S.C. 1983 that (1) TTU had violated their First Amendment rights by retaliating against them for constitutionally protected speech and (2) that TTU had violated the Fourteenth Amendment by denying them due process. They requested declaratory relief, a permanent injunction prohibiting TTU from similarly violating the rights in the future, removal of the Provost's punishments, attorney's fees, or other equitable relief like monetary losses. 

Although the plaintiff professors originally named the Provost, the Board of Trustees, and three staff members who had investigated the allegations as defendants, later, on November 19, 2021, plaintiffs requested and were granted a dismissal without prejudice of all the investigatory defendants. Accordingly, on November 29, 2021, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint removing the investigators but adding the president of TTU, who had decided that any TTU employees who had been disciplined were not eligible for a normal $1,000 bonus. On December 7, 2021, the Board of Trustees and the President moved to dismiss the actions against them, both claiming qualified immunity and that U.S.C. 1983 applies only to "persons," which courts have defined to exclude the state and officials acting in their official capacities. In their December 20, 2021 response, the plaintiffs agreed that the Board of Trustees should be dismissed.

On January 26, 2022, Judge Waverly D. Crenshaw, Jr. dismissed the Board of Trustees and the President as defendants in the case, leaving only the Provost. On June 2, 2022, the plaintiffs added a request for a preliminary injunction. On September 28, 2022, the plaintiffs filed for summary judgment. The Provost cross-motioned for summary judgment in her favor on September 30, 2022. On October 4, 2022, the mediator reported that the parties met for mediation on September 22, 2022, but the case did not settle.

On December 1, 2022 Judge Crenshaw closed the case by denying the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, granting the Provost's motion for summary judgment, and denying the preliminary injunction. 643 F.Supp.3d 824. On the First Amendment claims, she applied settled tests for public employees in school settings attempting to establish First Amendment retaliation: she reasoned that the plaintiffs had met their burdens to show that their speech had some elements of constitutionally protected speech, since the professors were hybrid private citizens and public employees speaking on a matter of public concern, that the action against them had been adverse enough to chill their speech, and that the Provost had disciplined the professors because of their speech (not merely their conduct). However, despite success in these areas of the test, she ultimately found the speech unprotected under a balancing test that asked whether the professor's interest in their First Amendment speech outweighed their employer's interest in public service efficiency. She recognized that university professors had a large interest in free speech, but found that the school's interest in building a collegial academic community where everyone was able to speak freely, reinforced by discipline, outweighed the professor's interest.

The Provost had also asserted qualified immunity, which would shield her from liability unless the plaintiffs put forth analogous case law showing that he violated "clearly defined rights." The Judge rejected the plaintiff's two attempts at analogy and held that they could not show that any reasonable person in the Provost's position would know it was unconstitutional to discipline them.

Last, the Judge rejected the plaintiff's due process claims, saying they had no cognizable property entitlement in auxiliary teaching function privileges like teaching abroad. She also found that the procedure had been adequate to confer due process: the Provost made a considered decision, relied on thorough investigations, and conducted some interviews herself. Although her rejection of the plaintiff's appeal of her decision was short, that was not a due process violation. 

Appeal

On December 16, 2022, the plaintiff-professors filed an appeal against the Provost and President of TTU in the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals. The Provost and President's brief is not due until March 1, 2023.
case_data.summary_short: The plaintiffs in this lawsuit are two Tennessee Tech University professors who put up a flier accusing one of their colleagues of racism. The University investigated and disciplined the professors, leading the professors to sue the University in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.  The district court case lasted from October 4, 2021 through December 1, 2022 and closed with summary judgment in favor of the University. The professors appealed in the 6th Circuit on December 16, 2022.

Dr. Donadio also attended the meeting.  Even though he understood that some people found

That same evening, Dr. Gruber contacted Mr. Smith by Facebook Messenger, and informed
him about what she had witnessed.  Upon hearing Dr. Donadioโs reaction, Mr. Smith, too, became

Dr. Donadioโs reaction to the Boardโs decision to shelf the issue about renaming the
โRedskins,โ coupled with his role as the faculty advisor to TPUSA, incensed Plaintiffs and prompted
Mr. Smith to create the flyer that is at the heart of this lawsuit.  Before discussing that flyer and its
aftermath, a little background about TPUSA and its arrival at TTU is appropriate.

racial controversyโ surrounding it.  (Id. ยถ 27).  They point out that โ[b]efore TPUSA had an official

which publishes profiles of college professors, and has the stated mission to โexpose and document

college professors who discriminate against conservative students and advance leftist propaganda

This racist college professor thought it would be a great idea to help start a Tennessee
Tech chapter for this national hate group, where racist students can unite to harass,

discipline included Plaintiffs being (1) not permitted to serve as a faculty advisor to any student
organizations; (2) not allowed to participate in study abroad activities; (3) ineligible for non-
instructional faculty assignments; and (4) ineligible for salary increases for a year.  Additionally, both
were required to meet with the Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences (or his or her designee) at
the start of each semester โto reinforce with you the importance of not bringing personal grievances
into the workplace.โ  (Id. at 2-3).  Plaintiffs were also required to complete sensitivity training.  (Id.). 
II. Legal Discussion
Mr. Smithโs flyer called Dr. Donadio a racist.  Words have meaning and college language
teachers should understand that better than most.  Perhaps, however, Dr. Gruber and Mr. Smith are
clever by half because, at least according to some:
Accusations of โracismโ no longer are โobviously and naturally harmfulโ. The word
has been watered down by overuse, becoming common coin in political discourse.
. . . Formerly a โracistโ was a believer in the superiority of one's own race, often a
supporter of slavery or segregation, or a fomenter of hatred among the races. . . .
Politicians sometimes use the term much more loosely, as referring to anyone (not
of the speaker's race) who opposes the speaker's political goalsโon the โrationaleโ
that the speaker espouses only what is good for the jurisdiction (or the audience), and
since oneโs opponents have no cause to oppose what is beneficial, their opposition
must be based on race. The term used this way means only: โHe is neither for me nor
of our race; and I invite you to vote your race.โ . . . That may be an unfortunate brand
of politics, but it also drains the term of its former, decidedly opprobrious, meaning.
. . .
8
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 90   Filed 12/01/22   Page 8 of 27 PageID #: 8920

Language is subject to leveling forces. When a word acquires a strong meaning it
becomes useful in rhetoric. A single word conveys a powerful image. When
plantation owners held blacks in chattel slavery, when 100 years later governors
declared โsegregation now, segregation foreverโ, everyone knew what a โracistโ was.
The strength of the image invites use. To obtain emotional impact, orators employed
the term without the strong justification, shading its meaning just a little. So long as
any part of the old meaning lingers, there is a tendency to invoke the word for its
impact rather than to convey a precise meaning. We may regret that the language is
losing the meaning of a word, especially when there is no ready substitute.  
Stevens v. Tillman, 855 F.2d 394, 402 (7th Cir. 1988).
The observations in Stevens are almost thirty-five years old. Matters have only gotten worse
since then, undoubtedly to the dismay of English language purists.  In many walks of life, including
academia it seems, civility and professionalism have taken a backseat to unnecessary discord and
divisiveness, with terms like โracistโ being bandied about with reckless abandon.  โBut we serve in
a court of law rather than of language and cannot insist that speakers cling to older meanings.โ  Id. 
Nor can a court legislate sensible behavior.  
What the Court can and must do is determine whether a genuine issue of material fact exists
on Plaintiffsโ First Amendment retaliation or Fourteenth Amendment due process claims and
whether either side is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. If there remains a jury question on a
claim, the question then becomes whether Defendant is entitled to qualified immunity.4
4  The Court analyzes these issues sequentially because, to overcome the qualified immunity defense,
plaintiffs must establish that (1) โbased upon the applicable law, the facts viewed in the light most favorable
to the plaintiffs show that a constitutional violation has occurred,โ and (2) โthe violation involved a clearly
established constitutional right of which a reasonable person would have known.โ  Sample v. Bailey, 409
F.3d 689, 695-96 (6th Cir.2005); see also Saucier v. Katz, 533 U.S. 194, 201 (2001). Although โthe court
may address these prongs in any order . . . if the plaintiff cannot make both showings, the offic[ial] is entitled
to qualified immunity.โ  Brown v. Lewis, 779 F.3d 401, 412 (6th Cir. 2015) (citing Pearson v. Callahan, 555
U.S. 223, 236 (2009)).  Hence, if โno constitutional violation occurred, the Court need not address [the
partiesโ] arguments regarding qualified immunity.โ  Fox v. Corrigan, 161 F. App'x 522, 526 (6th Cir. 2005);
see also Criss v. City of Kent, 867 F.2d 259, 261 (6th Cir. 1988) (observing that if โno constitutional
violation occurred . . . the court would never reach the qualified immunity questionโ).
9
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 90   Filed 12/01/22   Page 9 of 27 PageID #: 8921

A.  First Amendment Retaliation
โ[T]he Free Speech Clause applies at public universitiesโ and โ[t]hus, the state may not act
as though professors or students โshed their constitutional rights to freedom of speech or expression
at the [university] gate.โโ Meriwether v. Hartop, 992 F.3d 492, 503 (6th Cir. 2021) (quoting Tinker
v. Des Moines Indep. Cmty. Sch. Dist., 393 U.S. 503, 506 (1969)).  Nevertheless, โfree-speech rules

F.3d 887, 900 (6th Cir. 2019); accord Albrecht v. Treon, 617 F.3d 890, 894 (6th Cir. 2010).
As a preliminary matter, the parties dispute whether Plaintiffs were deprived of a property
interest, which โare not created by the Constitution,โ but, instead, โare created and their dimensions
are defined by existing rules or understandings that stem from an independent source such as state
law[.]โ  Cleveland Bd. of Educ. v. Loudermill, 470 U.S. 532, 538 (1985) (quoting Bd. of Regents
v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564, 576 (1972)).  Plaintiffs claim they were denied property interests when Dr.
Gruberโs grant was revoked, they were prohibited from study abroad trips, and they were subjected
to random visits to their classroom by the Dean of the College of Arts and Science.  According to
them, these actions limited their professional growth, stunted their careers, and damaged their
22
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 90   Filed 12/01/22   Page 22 of 27 PageID #: 8934

reputation.  
Plaintiffs rely on Smock v. Bd. of Regents of Univ. of Mich., 353 F. Supp.3d 651, 657 (E.D.
Mich. 2018) for the proposition that โprofessors may have a protected property interest in their jobs
duties if those responsibilities are essential to the employeeโs scholarship and academic standing.โ 
(Doc. No. 81 at 10).  Reliance on Smock is misplaced.  Not only was Smock decided in the context
of a motion to dismiss, underpinning its property interests discussion was the Supreme Courtโs
observation that โ[t]o have a property interest in a benefit a person must clearly have more than an
abstract need or desire and more than a unilateral expectation of it.  He must have a legitimate claim
of entitlement to it.โ  Colorado v. Gonzales, 545 U.S. 748, 756, 125 S.Ct. 2796, 162 L.Ed.2d 658
(2005).  The plaintiff in Smock arguably had a property interest in sabbatical leave because there
apparently was no discretion for the school to deny it, and arguably a property interest in his role as
a graduate student advisor under his contract with the school, although that was less clear.  353 F.
Supp. 3d at 656.  The same cannot be said here.
Undoubtedly, โgovernment employees have a cognizable property interest in their job if they
have tenure.โ Hasanaj v. Detroit Pub. Sch. Cmty. Dist., 35 F.4th 437, 448 (6th Cir. 2022).  Beyond
that, and โ[a]s a general rule, Sixth Circuit caselaw establishes that โtenured university professors
do not have a constitutionally protected property interest in administrative posts.โโ  Kaplan v. Univ.
of Louisville, 10 F.4th 569, 579 (6th Cir. 2021) (citation omitted).  The Sixth Circuit recognizes
โtwo potential exceptions to [its] general rule[:] [f]irst, a professor may have a property interest in
an administrative position that is itself a tenure-track appointment; [or second], an express guarantee
that the employee holds the administrative post subject to removal for cause might create a property
interest.โ  Id.  Both exceptions are in keeping with the Supreme Courtโs teaching that there must be
23
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 90   Filed 12/01/22   Page 23 of 27 PageID #: 8935

a legitimate claim of entitlement to the interest, and not just a desire, want, or need.
Plaintiffs have not shown a legitimate claim of entitlement to teaching abroad.  To the
contrary, Dr. Gruberโs contract stated that there was โno obligation for or guarantee of summer
session employment.โ (Doc. No. 88-2 at 4).  Mr. Smith never participated in study abroad activities
(Doc. No. 81-14, Smith Dep. at 168) and so he never had even a unilateral expectation of going
overseas as a part of his teaching duties.
Dr. Gruber has also not established that she was denied a grant.  What she was denied was
a โNon-Instructional Assignmentโ for research that allowed her to take time away from her teaching
duties.  This apparently does not prevent her from applying for grants or other funding that would
support her research and academic pursuits. (Doc. Nos.  81-13, Gruber Dep. 176-178; 62-22 at 3). 
Nor has it been shown that the Dean auditing class is somehow the loss of a property interest. 
To the contrary, Mr. Johnson testified that โof courseโ the Dean has the privilege to โdrop[] by my
class.โ  (Doc. No. 81-14, Johnson Dep. at 172).
โOnly after a plaintiff has met the burden of demonstrating that he possessed a protected
property or liberty interest and was deprived of that interest will the court consider whether the
process provided the plaintiff in conjunction with the deprivation, or lack thereof, violated his rights
to due process.โ   Hamilton v. Myers, 281 F.3d 520, 529 (6th Cir. 2002).  Because Plaintiffs have
not carried that burden, the Court could end here. However, as a matter of completeness, the Court
notes that Plaintiffs have not shown that they were deprived of adequate pre-deprivation procedures.
Plaintiffs complain that they were investigated under an inapplicable policy because, on
February 24, 2021, they were informed that an investigation had commenced under Policy 141,
Prohibited Discrimination and Harassment.  However, the same letter to both Plaintiffs states that 
24
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 90   Filed 12/01/22   Page 24 of 27 PageID #: 8936

Human Resources had received a complaint alleging misconduct in violation of Policy 202,
Academic Freedom and Responsibility, Policy 207, Tenured Faculty, and Policy 600, Code of
Conduct.  (Doc. No. 80-8 at 1, 3).  Those letters also plainly state, however, that the investigation
would be conducted under the โprocesses set forth in Policy 141, Prohibited Discrimination and
Harassment.โ  (Id.) (emphasis added).  In other words, Policy 141 provided the process for
considering whether they violated the code of conduct set forth in Policy 600.
Next, Plaintiffs complain that Defendants overlooked or ignored information, including a
โlist of documented reports of TPUSA officials at college campuses across the country espousing
racism,โ and Dr. Donadioโs and Ms. Sciolisโ participation in the Fox News program.  (Doc. No. 80
at 14).  Plaintiffs provide no cases suggesting that every kernel of information presented must be
examined analyzed when determining discipline.  This is likely because due process is a โflexible
inquiry,โ with  โ[d]ifferent  circumstances call[ing] for different processes.โ  Cunningham v.
Blackwell, 41 F.4th 530, 536 (6th Cir. 2022). โWhile โsome kind of a hearingโ generally must occur
before the State fires a tenured employee . . . , the same is not true for other discipline.โ  Id..  
To succeed on their due process claim, Plaintiffs must show that they were denied โadequate
procedural rights to protect against an erroneous deprivation.โ    Kaplan, 10 F.4th at 577 (emphasis
added).  They have not done so.  Quite the contrary, the record reflects that Dr. Bruceโs was a
considered decision.  Investigator Holt notified Plaintiffs of the Complaint and the procedural
process to be followed, reviewed relevant materials (the flyer, the police report, and the security
images) and interviewed both witnesses and the Plaintiffs.  He drafted an investigation report to Dr.
Stinson who  forwarded it to Dr. Bruce.  Dr. Bruce then re-interviewed witnesses (Dr. Gruber, Mr.
Smith, Ms. Sciolis, and Dr. Donadio), and reviewed the findings and investigative materials as well
25
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 90   Filed 12/01/22   Page 25 of 27 PageID #: 8937

as TTU policies.  She also conferred with TTUโs Faculty Senate President and Faculty Trustee before
making her final decision regarding discipline.  In short, Plaintiffs were provided all the process that
was due.
Finally, Plaintiffs complain that their rights were somehow violated when Dr. Bruce rejected
their appeal with the following three sentences:
I received a formal written document appealing the disciplinary action related to Case
# 2021-4 on June 17, 2021 via email from your lawyer, Mr. Robert Bigelow. I have
carefully reviewed the appeal documents that were submitted on your behalf and I
have also prudently reviewed the documentation related to the disciplinary action. I
found that the appropriate TTU policy (Policy 650) was in fact followed and that the
disciplinary action was reasonable and appropriate given the record.
(Doc. No. 81- 12 at 1).  Not only do Plaintiffs cite no cases to support the proposition that a lengthy
discourse  is  necessary  when  denying  an  appeal  for  reasons  already  given,  they  neglect  to
acknowledge that they were each sent a 3-page letter from Dr. Bruce on May 13, 2021 that discusses
her rationale imposing certain discipline.  Her rejection of the appeal required no further explanation. 
III.  Conclusion
On the basis of the foregoing, Plaintiffsโ Motion for Summary Judgment will be denied while
Defendantsโ Motions will be granted.  Further, because granting judgment in favor of Defendant
means that Plaintiffs have no likelihood of success on the merits within the meaning of Rule 65(a)
of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, Plaintiffsโ additional request for preliminary injunctive relief
will be denied.
An appropriate Order will enter.

MEMORANDUM OPINION AND ORDER
In this suit under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, Dr. Julia Gruber, an Associate Professor of German, and
Andrew Smith, a Senior Instructor of English, sue their employer, Tennessee Board of Trustees d/b/a
Tennessee Tech University, along with Dr. Philip Oldham, its President, and Dr. Lori Bruce, its
Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs.  Plaintiffs allege retaliation in violation of the First
Amendment for their exercise of free speech and the denial of due process in violation of the
Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.  By way of this lawsuit, Plaintiffs seek to
enjoin certain sanctions that have been imposed against them, such as โ1) Not being allowed to serve
as a faculty advisor to any student organization at the university, including student clubs, student
chapters of professional societies, and student honor societies, 2) Not being allowed to participate
in study abroad activities, including faculty-led trips with students, 3) Not being eligible for
non-instructional faculty assignments, including university level awards of non-instructional faculty
assignments or release from teaching duties for the purpose of administrative duties, 4) The
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 42   Filed 01/26/22   Page 1 of 5 PageID #: 190

revocation of Dr. Gruberโs grant, 5) Requiring meetings to discuss their classroom behavior, 6)
Subjecting them to unnecessary observation in the classroom, and 7) The threat of termination for
further disciplinary actions.โ  (Doc. No. 40 at 2).
Defendants have filed a โMotion for Partial Dismissalโ in which they request dismissal of
โPlaintiffsโ claims against Tennessee Technological University, Dr. Gruber in her official capacity,
and Dr. Oldham, in his official capacity.โ  (Doc. No. 34 at 1).  Defendants also request that they be
allowed fourteen days from this Courtโs ruling on the motion within which to file an Answer
because, while Rule 12(a)(4) automatically extends the period for responding to a complaint when
a motion to dismiss is filed, the rule does not indicate whether that extension applies to partial
motions as well.
Turning to the procedural issue first, although โthere is limited authority on the point, . . . 
the majority of federal courts that have addressed the issue have held that filing a partial motion to
dismiss does indeed extend the time to file a responsive pleading with respect to all claims, including
those not addressed in the motion.โ Compton v. City of Harrodsburg, 287 F.R.D. 401, 402 (E.D. Ky.
2012) (citing 5B Wright & Miller, FEDERAL PRACTICE AND PROCEDURE ยง 1346 (3d ed.)). As one
court has explained, not permitting an extension for partial motions to dismiss could result in dual-
track litigation whereby discovery is allowed on some but not all claims, and this could run afoul of
Rule 1โs command that the Federal Rules be construed to โโsecure the just, speedy, and inexpensive
determination of every action and proceeding.โโ  Kent Intโl, Inc. v. United States, 161 F. Supp. 3d
1340, 1342 (Ct. Intโl Trade 2016) (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 1).  Many decades ago, the district court
in Gerlach v. Mich. Bell Tel. Co., 448 F. Supp. 1168, 1174 (E.D. Mich.1978) held otherwise, but
that case seemingly โstands alone like an Appaloosa in a herd of Thoroughbreds, and this Court
2
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 42   Filed 01/26/22   Page 2 of 5 PageID #: 191

declines to follow its lead.โ  Compton, 287 F.R.D. at 402.
Resolution of the substantive issue is also relatively straightforward given the governing law.
In their response, โPlaintiffs agree that their claims against Tennessee Tech should be dismissedโ
but argue that โthe claims against Dr. Lori Bruce and Dr. Philip Oldham in their official capacities
must remain.โ  (Doc. No. 40 at 1, 4).  
By its very terms, an official capacity claim as permitted by the Ex Parte Young doctrine
means that  โa federal court can issue prospective injunctive and declaratory relief compelling a state
official to comply with federal lawโ even if that โcompliance might have an ancillary effect on the
state treasury[.]โ S & M Brands, Inc. v. Cooper, 527 F.3d 500, 507โ08 (6th Cir. 2008) (internal
citations omitted).  The difference between improper retroactive damages and those ancillary to a
prospective relief claim has been described as follows:
In distinguishing between forbidden monetary relief and permissible injunctive relief,
the Supreme Court has explained that โ[r]elief that in essence serves to compensate
a party injured in the past by an action of a state official in his official capacity that
was illegal under federal law is barred even when the state official is the named
defendant.โ Papasan v. Allain, 478 U.S. 265, 278, 106 S. Ct. 2932, 92 L. Ed.2d 209
(1986). โOn the other hand, relief that serves directly to bring an end to a present
violation of federal law is not barred by the Eleventh Amendment even though
accompanied  by  a  substantial  ancillary  effect  on  the  state  treasury.โ  Id.  The
ancillary-effect exception, we have explained, โis a narrow one.โ Kelley v. Metro.
County Bd. of Educ., 836 F.2d 986, 992 (6th Cir.1987). โThe dividing lineโ between
ancillary relief and essentially compensatory relief, we have also explained, โis
whether the money or the non-monetary injunction is the primary thrust of the suit.โ
Barton v. Summers, 293 F.3d 944, 949 (6th Cir.2002); id. (โIf the injunctive relief
sought by the plaintiff is truly prospective non-monetary relief, sovereign immunity
will not bar the suit simply because the state may be required to make incidental
expenditures in complying with the injunction.โ). We consider Eleventh Amendment
immunity, as well as any exceptions to it, on a claim-by-claim basis.
Ernst v. Rising, 427 F.3d 351, 367โ68 (6th Cir. 2005).
Given this authority, Plaintiffsโ claim against Dr. Oldham in his official capacity is clearly
3
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 42   Filed 01/26/22   Page 3 of 5 PageID #: 192

subject to dismissal.1  As to that Defendant, they simply allege:
132. Dr. Oldham, the President of Tennessee Tech, unilaterally decided that anyone
at Tennessee Tech who had been disciplined in the past year would not be eligible
for the $1,000 bonus normally received. 
133. Accordingly [because they were sanctioned by Dr. Bruce], Plaintiffs were both
denied a $1,000 bonus in May of 2021 due to the Sanctions and decisions of Dr.
Oldham.
 
(Doc. No.  Amended Complaint ยถยถ 132-33).  A claim for the retroactive payment of a one-time
$1,000 bonus that was not awarded for a prior yearโs service is simply not a claim for prospective
injunctive relief of which the money would be ancillary.  Rather, it is a request for relief that would
serve to compensate plaintiff for a past injury and is barred by the Eleventh Amendment.  Papasan,
478 U.S. at 278.  Plaintiffs present no real arguments to the contrary.
 The โthrustโ of the complaint against Dr. Bruce is entirely different, however.  She is the one
who imposed the sanctions identified at the start of this opinion that include non-monetary
punishment, and she allegedly did so in violation of Plaintiffsโ free speech right and without due
process.  While the Amended Complaintโs prayer for relief contains the phrase โmonetary losses,โ
it does do in the context of requesting that โthe Court permanently enjoin Defendants from violating
Plaintiffsโ rights or grant them other equivalent equitable relief, including monetary losses, and order
Defendants to revoke all of the Sanctions imposed on Plaintiffs and reinstate Plaintiffs to their full
teaching duties.โ  (Am. Cmpt. at 21).   โ[C]laims for reinstatement are prospective in nature and
1Plaintiffsโ claim against Dr. Oldham in his individual capacity may be subject to dismissal as well. 
An individual โis only liable for his or her own misconduct,โ Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 677 (2009),
and โcase law teaches that in order to impose individual liability upon a [government official] for engaging
in unconstitutional misconduct, it is a plaintiff's burden to specifically link the [officialโs] involvement to
the constitutional infirmity,โ Burley v. Gagacki, 834 F.3d 606, 615 (6th Cir. 2016).  However, Defendants
have not moved to dismiss the individual capacity claim against Dr. Oldham because, at the time of the filing
of the motion to dismiss, he had not been served in his individual capacity.  (Doc 34 at 1).
4
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 42   Filed 01/26/22   Page 4 of 5 PageID #: 193

appropriate subjects for Ex parte Young actions.โ  Carten v. Kent State Univ., 282 F.3d 391, 396 (6th
Cir. 2002)(citing Turker v. Ohio Depโt. of Rehab. and Corrs., 157 F.3d 453, 459 (6th Cir.1998)). 
Because the โthrustโ of Plaintiffs real claim against Dr. Bruce is to right the alleged wrongs and
those include non-monetary damages, the Court cannot dismiss the official capacity claim against
her.
Accordingly, Defendantsโ Motion for Partial Dismissal (Doc. No. 34) is GRANTED IN
PART and DENIED IN PART as follows: (1)  The Motion is GRANTED with respect to
Tennessee Board of Trustees d/b/a/ Tennessee Tech University, and that Defendant is hereby
DISMISSED; (2) The Motion is GRANTED with respect to the official capacity claim against Dr.
Philip Oldham, and that claim is DISMISSED; and (3) The Motion is DENIED with respect to the
official capacity claim against Dr. Lori Bruce.  Within fourteen (14) days of the date of entry of this
Order and Memorandum Opinion, the remaining Defendants shall file an Answer (or Answers) to
the Amended Complaint.
IT IS SO ORDERED.

COMES  NOW,  the  Plaintiffs,  Dr.  JULIA  GRUBER  (โDr.  Gruberโ)  and  ANDREW 
SMITH (โProfessor Smithโ) (collectively โPlaintiffsโ), and brings suit against the Defendants 
TENNESSEE TECH UNIVERSITY (โTennessee Techโ or โDefendantโ), DR. LORI BRUCE 
(โDr. Bruceโ), and DR. PHILIP OLDHAM (โDr. Oldhamโ).  In support of their Complaint, the 
Plaintiffs state as follows: 
PARTIES, JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
1.  Dr. Julia Gruber lives in Putnam County, Tennessee, and is an Associate Professor of 
German at Tennessee Tech. 
2.  Professor Andrew Smith is a resident of Putnam County, Tennessee, and is a Senior 
Instructor of English at Tennessee Tech. 
  1

3.  Defendant Tennessee Tech is a public university doing business in Cookeville, Tennessee.   
4.  Defendant  Board  of  Trustees  is  the  statutory  body  which  governs  the  control  and 
management of Tennessee Tech, as provided by Tenn. Code Ann. ยง 49-8-101 et seq.     
5.  Defendant Dr. Lori Bruce is an employee of Tennessee Tech, who in the scope of her job 
duties as Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs, made decisions against the interests of 
Plaintiffs that violated their First Amendment rights. 
6.  Defendant Dr. Philip Oldham is an employee of Tennessee Tech, who in the scope of his 
job duties as President of Tennessee Tech, made decisions against the interests of Plaintiffs that 
violated their First Amendment rights.   
7.  Plaintiffs assert claims under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 against Defendants for retaliation in 
violation of Plaintiffsโ Free Speech Rights pursuant to the First Amendment of the United States 
Constitution, and for violation of Plaintiffsโ Procedural Due Process rights pursuant to  the 
Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.  
8.  This Court has jurisdiction over the Plaintiffsโ federal law claims pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 
1331.   
9.  Venue is proper in the Middle District of Tennessee, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b) 
because a substantial part of the events giving rise to these claims occurred in Putnam County, 
Tennessee, and each of the Defendants reside or transact business in the Middle District of 
Tennessee.   
  2

FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
Dr. Julia Gruber 
10.  Dr. Gruber is an Associate Professor of German at Tennessee Tech.  
11.  Dr. Gruber is a tenured professor who has been working at Tennessee Tech for over 13 
years. 
12.  Dr. Gruber has received outstanding job evaluations, resulting in consistent pay raises since 
she started working at Tennessee Tech in 2008. 
13.  Because of her outstanding performance, Dr. Gruber has been the highest paid faculty 
member in her department for years, even though she is not the most senior faculty member. 
14.  Dr. Gruber expected to receive another raise in 2021, as well as a $1,000 bonus normally 
given to faculty who earn a satisfactory evaluation. 
15.  In 2020, Dr. Gruber was awarded a Non-Instructional Grant (the โGrantโ), which she chose 
to take in the Spring Semester of 2022.  She had never received this Grant before. 
16.  The Grant was awarded to Dr. Gruber after a committee of faculty members selected Dr. 
Gruberโs proposal.  Her proposal focused on bringing African-American and Caucasian women 
together to discuss female anger at racism and misogyny.   
17.  The  Grant  would  have  allowed  Dr.  Gruber  to  take  a  semester  off  from  teaching 
assignments, while being paid her regular monthly income of $5,416.84 (gross) or $3,859.12 
(net).    
18.  The Grant also provided Dr. Gruber an extra $4,000 to cover conference travel and 
expenses to host a virtual workshop.   
19.  Grants are highly competitive, and only a small number are awarded each year at Tennessee 
Tech.   
  3 
Case 2:21-cv-00039   Document 33   Filed 11/29/21   Page 3 of 22 PageID #: 141

20.  Grants are crucial for university professors as they allow them to free their schedules from 
teaching and service for one semester, to focus on research. 
21.  The three main areas that professors are evaluated on each year at Tennessee Tech are 
teaching, research, and service.  
22.  Grants are a key determining factor when deciding which professors receive promotions. 
23.  Grants are also given substantial weight when universities make hiring decisions.      
24.  After the Grant was approved, Dr. Gruber notified the Coalition of Women in German, an 
organization she is involved with, that she had been awarded the funds to organize the workshop.   
25.  Dr. Gruber has taken Tennessee Tech students to Berlin (and Vienna) for study abroad trips 
almost every year since 2009.  She was paid for organizing and conducting one of those trips.  
26.  Some of her former students have written to her to express how much those trips changed 
their lives. 
27.  Dr. Gruber served as the Faculty Advisor of Tennessee Techโs German Club since 2008.   
28.  Additionally, Dr. Gruber also served as the Faculty Advisor of Tennessee Techโs Lambda
